I think that euthanasia should be an option for people to have. I am not suggesting this option be accessible to people with depression and see it as a means to end their lives. This should be open to people who have terminal cancer or other such fatal diseases and no longer want to continue suffering. There are such cases where it must be exceptionally painful and if one is going to die in a short period of time anyways, euthanasia should be an option that is available. I am not of the mind that people should be forced to stay alive and suffer if they are going to die soon anyways. If people are desperate enough, they are certainly willing to take it upon themselves to end their own lives. I would much rather have "assisted suicide" where there are other people who are aware of the happenings and can immediately report the death than people hanging themselves or slitting their wrists and then be found in their homes a week later. Those who are suffereing have the right to decide whether they want to live or not.
I just think that the govornment should withdraw from regulating any essentially private act.

I think the only danger is people thinking they want to die when they don't really. To rectify this, the person who wants to commit suicide should have to sign a form every week for several months to make sure it's something they want to do. After all, there's going back once it's done - that's the whole point!

As I understand the modern sense of the term "Euthanasia", there seem to be two categories that are discussed:
 
 1) Doctor-assisted suicide: Here I agree that a person has the right to kill themselves when they are in such a miserable state of health that continued life no longer has any purpose. It would be cruel to force them to continue living when there is no hope or negligeable hope of recovery. The only caveat that I would add is that there are situations in which a patient might get depressed to the point of suicide where those situations do promise a reasonable hope of recovery. In such situations, I would advocate a delay before any such decision is implemented to allow for psychotherapy and for the patient to possibly change their minds.
 
 2) Disconnecting a patient in long-term / terminal coma: If a person is in a persistent vegitative state or otherwise not able to communicate and there is no or negligeable hope of recovery, then I believe that at some point a decision has to be made whether or not to "unplug" the patient, thereby causing their death. I strongly support people's right to write living wills to outline the circumstances under which they should be disconnected. Otherwise, loved ones should usually make such decisions. When there is a dispute, such as in the Terry Schiavo case, then the state should then have the right to intervene, taking into account the state of the patient as determined by the medical expertise.
 
 So, in those two cases, I do support Euthanasia. However, it has an older malevolent meaning as well - as in Hitler killing the mentally ill or mentally challenged for the purpose of ratial purity. I highly doubt that anyone other than fringe nutcases are advocating for that type of Euthanasia.

Agreed. This forum subject pops up on a regular basis and generally divides itself into belief system advocates locked in by dogma and all others.  This is very general and bold statement. I have had a loved one (my grandfather) who had to go through a very long time in pain and suffering, in fact, he was at it for around a year.
 
 None the less, I would never vote in favour of legalising euthanasia, because I think it's a huge violation of the value of human life. Just because you're in pain doesn't mean that your life is worth less than before. A doctor suggested to my grandmother that we should consider euthanasia for my grandfather around 6 monthis into the disease. I found it absolutely abhorrent, to murder my grandfather just because he was no longer having a "worthy life". My grandmother thought the same, and my grandfather was also against it, when we told him. Fortunately in my country euthanasia is illegal anyways.
 
 Euthanasia is like saying that human life only has any value when you're not unhappy, and I definetly don't agree with this.
 
 The only chance I think euthanasia is plausible is when the person is already practically dead but is artificially sustained by machines or medicines. This is the only case of euthanasia I would agree with.

 Euthanasia is a person of sound mind facing a painful or debilitating condition that will ultimately lead to their death making the conscious and informed choice to end their life. It is not a doctors place to suggest such a thing. It is a decision that should be made by the patient and his/her designated agents only. It has nothing to do with the "value" of life, or the worth of life...especially when it is the patient who determines the course in the first place. And more importantly, it is an individual decision that the government or private citizens not directly involved in the case should keep their nose out of. 
 
 
The only chance I think euthanasia is plausible is when the person is already practically dead but is artificially sustained by machines or medicines. This is the only case of euthanasia I would agree with.

 This is not true euthanasia either. This is a normal withdrawl of care or life support. This thankfully is already legal in the US when a patient meets certain criteria. I for one do not want to be left on a ventilator, feeding tube, or in a comatose state for years. These are decisions that are already spelled out in living wills, or are left to a patients power of attorney to decide. While they are end of life issues, this is not euthanasia.

I think the only danger is people thinking they want to die when they don't really. To rectify this, the person who wants to commit suicide should have to sign a form every week for several months to make sure it's something they want to do. After all, there's going back once it's done - that's the whole point!

 
 But who's to say when they're sane and insane. If one moment they want to kill themselves and in a week they don't, and in another week they do, was he/she sane for that week? Or did they just go crazy and forget how bad their life was? I say unless there is a real mental disorder/disease, let them die. It's their life. I'm surprised that all these "pro-life" people seem to be against Euthanasia. Isn't the greatest show of being able to controll your own LIFE the right to end it? Unless we can prove that they are not mentally well, let them die. Now any doctor who tries to convince their patients to die should in my opinion be immediately fired and stripped of their doctor's liscense. They should be able to inform the patient of the option, but trying to sway them towards death is the dirtiest thing you could ever pull. If they really want to die, let them. But it's not your job to convince them that they want to die, even if you are really looking out for their best interest.

Fortunately in my country euthanasia is illegal anyways.
 
 Euthanasia is like saying that human life only has any value when you're not unhappy, and I definetly don't agree with this.
 

 
 It was your choice, why is it fortunate that euthanasia is illegal? If it were legal it's not like they would have murdered your Grandpa. You and your family would have said no, and the same thing would have happened.
 
 
 No, it's like saying if you think your life has no value left because you're terminally ill, a vegetable, or whatever, then you have the CHOICE to kill yourself.

To what degree will we as a society go to protect people from themselves? If a patient makes it obvious over a period of 3-4 months that they want to die, and it is established that they are in a constant state of sanity or insanity, we should let them go. This life should not be a jail; a person should not be forced to stay. There are numerous circumstances in which a sane person may want to end their life: 1) Dependence on perscription drugs 2) Paralasys 3) life imprisionment 4) Terminal illness 5) Serious post-war syndrome; more can be added to this list. Tax money should not be allocated to a person who has expressed numerous time in a row that they want to end their stay on Earth. The religious argument should be kept out of government legelation. Article 11 of the Treaty of Tripoli, along with our 1st Amendment establishes religious neutrality, and the euthenasia debate needs to be established with that same neutrality.

 I disagree wth this statement 100%. Lets take a look at why I disagree.
 
 1. Dependence on prescribtion drugs- That is almost the whole population of people worlwide. That are on sevral types of prescription drugs. Because of high blood pressure, blood sugar, mental illness, athritis, etc. That dose not mean that they should be able to end their lives because of it? As a matter of fact, alot of the pills give people such bad side effects. Lessening the dosage has rendered successful results. Allowing people to kill themselves, just because they take too many pills is not all together a wise course of action.
 
 2. Just because someone is paralaised dose not mean that is an excuse for suicide. I have taken care of patients that lead happy lives even though they can't move. Family is involved in their lives. And although there are times when a person has noone, in that instance a program set up, to work with those mentally who are restricted with their movement, should be put in place. To better help those deal with the situation that they are in.

The goverment is poking their noses where it shouldn't be. Almost every religion in the united states says that suicide, or euthanisa is a sin. THE ULTIMATE SIN! EUTHANISA IS MURDER!!!!!!!!!!!emoticon_angry emoticon_angry emoticon_angry

The goverment is poking their noses where it shouldn't be. Almost every religion in the united states says that suicide, or euthanisa is a sin. THE ULTIMATE SIN! EUTHANISA IS MURDER!!!!!!!!!!!emoticon_angry emoticon_angry emoticon_angry

 
 I think you've got it backward. It doesn't matter what a religion says about something and since it is illegal now, the govt. isn't really 'poking their noses'. However, it would be best for the govt. and any organized superstition to keep its noses out of MY business, if I choose to end my life for some reason. I find it offensive to think that you, your 'god', or your senator knows better than I what is best for me!

I have a problem with this debate. It seems to revolved around two different topics...
 
 1) Suicide - one taking one's own life
 
 2) Euthanasia - one taking ANOTHER'S life out of mercy.
 
 I see arguments about euthanizing the mentally ill and abortion. This is probably not the intention of this debate.
 
 For suicide... I say "Yes", under conditions. Psychological determination of sound mind and you cannot force a doctor to perform such an act (goes against their Hippocratic Oath).
 
 For euthanasia of the terminally comatosed... that's a tough one. First of all, it is always subjective for doctors to diagnose a "terminally" comatosed patient. The brain is very unpredictable and who is to decide the cut-off. If not specifically detailed in a will, can the government force a family to continue paying for the care of a terminally comatosed patient? Even if specific detailed in a will, what occurs if another party or doctor claims that the patient is not "terminal" and there is a chance of awakening? Too many if's. This might be have to be judged on a case-by-case basis.

NO! NO! NO! Capitol punishment is murder no matter how you look at it. Taking a life for a life or lives, is not punishment. It simply lets the criminal off the hook so to speak. They don't have to live with what they've done, to suffer in prison, instead they are releases from punishment through death. Oh we sure show them. :xbanghead

You're confusing Euthanasia with Capital Punishment, nutter.
 
 Euthanasia is not a punishment - it is committed as a mercy to the patient. Not to fully healthy criminals.
If you're laying in a hospital bed in a coma, and you have no chance of waking up ever again, then by using machines, the doctors aren't prolonging your life. They're prolonging your death.
This practice to kill the sick was used in Nazi Germany.The sick and disabled were a prelude to The Holocaust.I see the word euthanasia in hell as well as the word abortion.

This practice to kill the sick was used in Nazi Germany.The sick and disabled were a prelude to The Holocaust.I see the word euthanasia in hell as well as the word abortion.

 
 The difference is that the Nazi's used it against peoples will. Euthanasia and assisted suicide are done with the person's consent. Just a small difference there.

The difference is that the Nazi's used it against peoples will. Euthanasia and assisted suicide are done with the person's consent. Just a small difference there.
No matter whose will,euthanasia is a capital crime and genocide,period.

No matter whose will,euthanasia is a capital crime and genocide,period.

 
 Genocide has nothing to do with euthanasia. It appears that you don't know the meanings of either word.

If euthanasia is made legal it doesn't take too much effort to see the slippery slope where people are encouraged to go for it. Especially those who are vulnerable. You can make all the laws you like but that won't stop the persuasion. If you can trust all your fellow human beings 100% then maybe OK in some circumstances.
 
 BTW re living wills if you want to change your mind and are unconscious, how do you do it ?

BTW re living wills if you want to change your mind and are unconscious, how do you do it ?

 
 Un-conscious. How can you want to do anything if you are unconscious? Think about that.

Sorry a bit difficult for you.
 
 How does anyone know that if before you lapsed into an unconcious state you wanted to carry on living regardless?

Sorry a bit difficult for you.
 
 How does anyone know that if before you lapsed into an unconcious state you wanted to carry on living regardless?

 
 Not difficult for me, just pointing out your obvious difficulty in conveying your point clearly. 
 
 They don't. Living wills are designed to convey your wishes only should you become incapacitated. If you are able to verbally or otherwise make your wishes known before lapsing into an unconscious state, the living will is essentially a meaningless document. If you are unable to make your needs known, then you had better hope that you have been responsible enough to keep your living will up to date with your wishes. That is why they are called "advance directives". It is something you do ahead of time in order for people to be able to know what your wishes are should you no longer be able to tell them.
 
 Besides, not many people approach such decisions with a flippant attitude. I would suggest that if you were to make such a document, that you have crafted it to reflect your deepest beliefs and desires. I have had mine since I was 28, and should I decide to change my mind about something, it is my responsibility to make my living will reflect such a change.
